in time in a person's life so seasons of your life where this question's become

do it by really examining um uh what do users need What do users want And in the
design thinking framework we always say you don't start with a problem you start with people You start with empathy And
so in design thinking um the the empathy start when you're talking about your
life is to really examine who it is that you are and what it is that you think you want You know and this isn't an easy
thing to do because if it were easy to know what you would want and then it was kind of a linear okay now I'll just go get that Um this wouldn't be a hard
problem But in fact it's a very hard problem because people don't know what they want If you were part of the first
session I I mentioned that we're kind of the anti-passion guys Passion works for some people If you've got a passion
you've always wanted to be a chef you've always wanted to be a doctor and that that turns out to play out to be true
when you actually are one that's great But the the research says that only 20% of the people have an identifiable
passion 80% of everybody else has lots of things they like lots of ways in which they might express themselves in
the world that they could be excited about but no one thing rises to that that one overarching passion And so we
don't like processes that start with 80% of the people excluded But you can examine your life
and you can find ways to design into your future But here's the thing We'll
make it I want to make a distinction right now between what we call navigation and wayfinding Navigation we
all understand right We all have GPS on our phone or in our car and if somebody says how do I get to San
Francisco to this you know particular restaurant I just punch the the restaurant's address into my GPS and it
navigates me to there I go up Highway 280 I get off on you know Sixth Street D
But that's because I know exactly where I'm going So a navigation process can give me d explicit directions The
problem with designing your life is you don't exactly know where you're going You kind of have a sense of maybe I like this kind of stuff versus that kind of
stuff Again if you joined us for the first program you did a flow journal and you did an energy map both of and we had
some people send in some great stuff from the first webinar Um and we're still sort of processing some of that
information but that that you know the flow journal and the energy map kind of gives you a sense of well what works for
me more often than not how do I start to understand or examine which things might
be available to me that actually uh I get excitement or energy around And so
when you don't know where you're going but you still need to get there um use a
process we call wavefinding that I think lots of people have used this term Wayfinding is a method of figuring out
where you're going This is the way hunters find game in the wild They know there's a they know there's a antelope
or a deer out there someplace They know how to track for signs of the deer they kind of wander around going from point
to point um looking at the next set of signs or tracks or signals and
eventually they find the deer So uh we can do the same thing with finding that thing that really gets you excited in
terms of your career or other things in your life by using a process of wayinding which is simply to say what do
I know about myself right now what is available for me to try and talk about prototyping in a second and uh how do I
get to that next step and the next step has to be available and it has to be um operationable or or actionable So the
examined life in this case is all about practicing wayfinding Now there's a classic tension
in sort of uh modern western world I think or maybe in all the industrialized world and that's the tension between
being and doing you know uh particularly in uh Silicon Valley here Everybody's doing something Everybody's got a
startup Everybody's you know trying to actualize themselves through doing but they're not taking any time to examine
or understand whether the doing is getting them where they want to go And uh particularly in the mid-career
workshops we meet a lot of people who are very successful lawyers entrepreneurs technologists whatever Um
and they've made a lot of money and they've even had a lot of um uh personal success in their businesses They're the
senior vice president of something or the CEO of something But they report that um
somehow or other like in the Ellen Watts video when they got to the end and they opened the bag there was nothing in it
they discovered that somehow in all this doing they missed the being Now the flip side is you know just just being in the
world just being in the moment and kind of savoring your experiences um doesn't generate uh traction or action in the
direction of your goals Um so if you stay inside what we call this classic
tension in western modern society you're kind of stuck and we don't like being stuck So we're going to reframe this as
what we're going to call the voice discovery engine or the the the wayfinding engine for your journey Uh we
have a the original class of this we started all this which was called the designer's voice started with this
concept of you know voice Who who am I Who's my authentic person When I speak about something when I talk about
something I have a a voice a sort of authenticity when the things I'm saying are true for me And so you know when
you're trying to figure out where you're going you have to sort of try to untangle all the different things that are interesting to you or things that
that make you stuck or whatever And this we call sort of voice discovery or your path discovery And we reframe the
classic tension between being doing into what we're going to call the being doing becoming cycle Right So this this engine
which continues to rotate constantly in your life uh overcomes the false
dichotomy of I can either be achieving or I can be experiencing It's really not
the way it works The way it works for people and the way you discover a passion or you discover the thing that
you want to do next is through this being doing and becoming So I I do stuff in the world I take action I make a
prototype I uh flow journal I do my um other practices and exercises to try to
figure out uh uh what I like right to sort of navigate towards the next thing
In the process of doing these things I change who I am I change what's possible for me And then in the process
of that change I be I become and and rest in a state of a new awareness I my
my enjoyment is increased my ability to savor has been amplified So it's sort of
like you know um I have had season tickets to the ballet My wife and I love the ballet We go out every year Um and a
couple of years ago the ballet started putting little short videos up uh prior to each performance which showed a
little piece of the performance from the previous year a little voiceover dialogue from the conductor about what
uh the music was all about from the choreographer about what the dance was all about And I found that by just disco
discovering that and then watching that little eight or nine minute thing before the ballet all of a sudden my enjoyment
of the ballet is significantly increased Right Because I have done something I've become a more uh adept connoisseur of
the ballet and now my enjoyment my being at the ballet is completely different
experience So if you if you just take this reframe from the false dichotomy of
I'm either doing something or I'm being something but I can't be both at the same time and realize it's actually a
cyclical process That's the first step first reframe Now if you're going to design
stuff you're going to make decisions Design is really if you just boil it all down forget our diagrams and everything
else Design is just a series of decisions I want to make a new coffee cup I have to make a series of decisions What's going to be different What will
be new Will it be bigger or smaller Will it be made of paper or or um ceramic So
all these decisions add up to design but how do I know I'm making a good decision This is the big thing people wrestle
with when they're when they're stuck They go "Wow I've got all these different things I could do but I don't know how to make a good decision." And
we're going to argue that in order to make a good decision you need more than just your logic because you know the
questions you're asking yourself about life don't always resolve just by looking at them logically So we have
this notion that the examined life requires examination and therefore you're going to have to get good at this You're going to have to develop some
practices that this reflective practice the practice of being able to to do what
we call discernment is critical to insight and decision-making and that discernment empowers
um a lot of things including how to get information from the community around you and how to get information from your
mentors So the keys to this practice and discernment thing is
is paying attention I'm going to talk about that in a little bit And then ways of knowing
how do we know when we've made a good decision How do we know when the decision is right for
us Paying attention Paying attention is part of this being and becoming uh
engine And paying attention has two parts Um noticing which is attending to
things while they're happening at the time being present in the awareness of your experience right now and reflection

some time each day reflecting on your experience Um several several people who

one of the most powerful things you can do is after every meeting after every engagement after every interview or
every every you know ch sort of chunk of your day stop for a moment just a few moments and write down the two or three

to we're going to talk to to this issue of noticing and reflecting because it's

He's a very smart person He didn't have the ability to make decisions because he had no emotional veilance on the

um and others Um and it turns out to be one of the simplest things Uh again this

even a yoga practice None none of those if you do it that way that's fine but

500 calories of that So it's evolved over time to sort of use as much energy
as is possible If you use more than that probably the rest of the body wouldn't have enough energy to run But even so that's not much That's

um uh you know parsimmonious in terms of how it uses its attention and most of
the time you're not actually attending to things very much You're just sort of processing and moving forward um because
your brain likes to be lazy So this gratefulness exercise seems to work and
there's tons and tons of evidence from you know modern psychology now that this will significantly change
um a person's uh mood or set point I mean everybody has a certain set point
You can't turn a tigger into an Eeyore or an Eeyore into a or a poo But
whatever your set point is you can maximize um your sense of well-being your sense
of thriving your sense of happiness by simply spending some time in a couple of
structured ways to redirect your attention to um things that are more
positive This exercise is an exercise in that regard and it's really quite simple
Um just set aside 10 minutes even five minutes a day But it's important because it's a practice that it becomes a
regularly practiced thing in everyday occurrence Leave a journal or a piece of
paper or something next to your bed or you know whenever you have that um you
know a glass of wine or whatever at the end of the day Um set aside 10 minutes
and think about your day Recall the day and look for uh things or episodes experiences little moments of things
that you are grateful for Jot down two or two to five of these events or exchanges every day and then focus on
them Relive the experience of that moment Just kind of rever it Um repeat
until all your moments are complete and that's it And then every week or so on
the weekend maybe scan that list of things that you're grateful for If you have two every day you'll have 10 or or
14 moments where something happened that you were grateful for And we're looking
for patterns So we're going to use both the attention uh in reflective attention looking back
on something And then we're going to use the pattern matching skill that we are innately born with to see if we can find
a pattern in this uh set of episodes that we're grateful for Now this is this can be super simple
things like uh the lady at the Starbucks smiled when she handed me my coffee and
said "Have a nice day." And I just noticed that that was sweet Or um uh you
know I was uh I forgot my headphones on the bus and I was just about to get off the bus and somebody next to me said "Oh
did you drop these?" And it was like "Oh that's great." I because I lose you know I lose stuff on all the time and it's
nice when someone picks something up for me So it doesn't have to be you know somebody um you know rescued my dog or
you know saved my life This is just small interventions in the day where
you're going to try to look for a positive bias Um the data says that if you do
this and you make this a regular part of your practice within six to eight weeks if this becomes a habit and psychology
tells us it takes about eight weeks to form a new habit Um people surveyed pre and post this simple practice um have a
significantly higher sense of well-being a significantly higher sense of energy a significantly higher sense of of u you
know their their happiness and sort of agency in the world When that starts to happen and and
you notice patterns of these behaviors you will start to unconsciously provoke these behaviors in yourself and others
And that will lead to new opportunities for prototypes new things that you could try And that starts you on the path of

Which brings us to the the final thing that in the design thinking paradigm we spent a lot of time talking about
prototyping You can prototype new products new experiences Um you know when uh the whole notion of design
thinking is if we're going to invent something new we're kind of inventing the future But you can't get any data about the future Nobody knew what the
iPhone was until they started sort of tinkering around and building prototypes and trying different things And if you
read the the first biography of of Steve Jobs you you know that they turned he turned the iPhone down three times
because it wasn't good enough So it was a con constant and relentless process of prototyping and trying things and saying
is this what going to work And then when we when we say is this what's going to work we show it to lots of people and
then they change their mind about what they want and then they tell us new things and then we just keep doing that until we finally invent something that
people recognize They go "Oh that's what I wanted." Well that's what we're going to try to do with prototyping our way
forward in lives in our lives We say in at the D school we say building is thinking It's not that we think of
something and then go make a model of it and say "How about this?" We actually use the process of modeling
or prototyping to think our way forward So this is a form of practice in
life design Prototyping uh prototypes is prototypes are experiences that you design to ask an
interesting question So this isn't just necessarily completely solve the problem Although sometimes prototypes do end up
solving a problem or a question that you've got But mostly we create prototypes to ask an interesting
question What would it be like You know I've got a lot of students who come to Stanford and they want to become they're
they they enter the premedical uh major Um uh we have a couple of majors here that you can do for premed because they
want to be doctors And I go "Why do you want to be a doctor?" They go "I don't know I've always wanted to be a doctor." And I go "That's that's great Do you have any idea what a doctor actually
does every day?" They go "No." Um I go "Well that's an easy that's an easy
question to ask What does a doctor do every day?" And um since we have a big medical school here and the doctors are
always looking for students to work in their labs it's pretty easy to go find out um it's pretty easy to go get an
opportunity to shadow a doctor or spend an hour with a doctor um interviewing you know a dozen doctors and finding out
what they actually do every day Interesting in that situation most of my students come back and go
wow you know mostly it's really boring I mean the part about surgery was
cool but all the rest of it seems really boring Um so a a prototype is a thing
you designed to ask an interesting questions They're really the only way we know to get data about your possible future And you want them to be as low
resolution and as brief and as inexpensive in both your time and your money as possible because you want to
run lots and lots and lots of prototypes It's this design iterate design iterate building your way forward um is the
methodology And so you're constantly looking for ways to say well what's a what's available What what is possible
for me to do Can I get a hold of a doctor Can I get a hold of a a person who does this thing I'm interested in doing and spend some time with them And
uh Michael uh Shrege who wrote a book MIT Press called Serious Play um has got
done a whole PhD study on how prototyping uh impacts the quality of design So it's a great book and he says
you know the value of prototypes rely less in the models themselves the things you create but in the interactions they
invite Um you you often go out asking one question with your prototype and come back with a whole bunch of
different answers to other questions that turned out to be more important than the one you thought you were asking
So forms of practice for this examples of prototyping in a life design scenario are an information interview You know
80% of the jobs are never listed Um and so people who say "Oh you know I tried I've sent the resume into everything on
the internet and I didn't get any didn't even get any answers back." Um I go "Great Well you've only you've only hit
20% of the possible opportunities out there and the rest you're not going to find on the internet." And by the way
just as a as a tip sending resumes into internet posting posted jobs has about a
2 to 5% hit rate So you can send in a hundred and maybe get two answers back Um and that don't even lead to
interviews And and also by the way about half of the jobs that are listed on the internet uh have already been filled in
that um most companies have a practice of saying hey if you want to hire somebody you have to post the job So if
I know I want to hire Karen to be my um you know my facilitator for my executive
programs Um I'll post a job with a description of someone who looks just like Karen Wait the one week I have to
wait by my company's rules and then just hire the person I was going to hire anyway So most of the stuff you see
listed isn't actually real Um but I digress Back to the prototypes You know
you can have an information interview which is a great way to find out if the thing that you're interested in doing even exists and whether it's really the
thing you think it is You can spend a day shadowing someone This is fantastic Uh you know students do it um
professionals do it It's amazing the kind of information you get about people and the conversations you'll have during
that day Um that might take you down new paths what we call a pop-up experience We u often run um some of our most
popular classes now at Stanford last a day or two or three a weekend Uh so you can create popup experiences to see if
you wanted to do the thing you want to do One of the things we do with entrepreneurs um is have them um you
know just pop up a version of the product or or service that they want to offer uh in its crudest form and see if
they like selling it for the for a weekend Um we're actually about to have head off to Makers Fair uh here in in
the Valley this weekend is the big Makers Fair event and I've got all I've got eight of my students team at Makers
Fair trying to see if if one if people really like the products they've come up with and two if they really like
spending 48 hours uh in in selling mode
If not they're probably not entrepreneurs You can create internships Everybody loves to have an intern and
they even love it even more if you don't have to pay them um and uh a oneweek unpaid experience doing what you want to
